Roy,

The issue here is whether resources parametrized by HTTP-auth or cookies 
are RESTful; whether e.g. two different bank accounts are different 
"representations" of the same underlying resource.  Here is what you said 
in your dissertation:
<http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/rest_arch_style.htm>

"""
The central feature that distinguishes the REST architectural style from 
other network-based styles is its emphasis on a uniform interface between 
components (Figure 5-6)[...]
In order to obtain a uniform interface, multiple architectural constraints 
are needed to guide the behavior of components. REST is defined by four 
interface constraints: identification of resources; manipulation of 
resources through representations; self-descriptive messages; and, 
hypermedia as the engine of application state. These constraints will be 
discussed in Section 5.2.
"""

And in section 5.2 you say:

"""
More precisely, a resource R is a temporally varying membership function 
MR(t), which for time t maps to a set of entities, or values, which are 
equivalent. The values in the set may be resource representations and/or 
resource identifiers
"""

So, if my credit card company exposes 
<https://www.accountonline.com/AccountSummary>,
the content of which varies depending on a cookie, do you believe that 
response to a request for this URI is a representation of a REST style 
Resource?  In particular, do you believe that my account information and 
your account information are really different representations of the same 
underlying resource (that they are "equivalent") or that the resource 
identified by this URI is simply changing rapidly depending on which of us 
is making a request at that exact moment?

Alternatively, if my credit card company starts using HTTP-auth instead of 
cookie-auth, would that somehow make your account data and my account data 
different representations of the same underlying resource?

Note to Walden and the other folks on the legal-subpoena thread: We all 
have a pretty clear notion of what "my account" means.  That the content of 
my account changes over time (because I spend money or others steal it), 
doesn't change its identity (Herclitus/flux arguments notwithstanding). 
The issue here is simply whether or not the concept of "Representation" in 
Representational State Transfer is sufficiently broad so that a 
"Representation" is nothing more than the content return by an HTTP server 
at a specific moment in time.

-Alex-

--On Friday, July 04, 2003 6:13 PM +0200 "Roy T. Fielding" 
<fielding@...> wrote:

> Crikey, you guys are getting all mixed up.  REST is defined by
> my dissertation.  REST is not defined by the TAG discussion or
> the W3C's Webarch document or TimBL's design notes.  REST is an
> architectural style, not the Web architecture.  Please try
> to keep the terminology consistent.
>
> REST does not claim that all important resources must have identifiers.
> REST merely requires that actions be applied to an identified resource,
> and that identification be in the form of a resource identifier (rather
> than, for example, a sequence of events).  Obviously, if you do not
> have an identifier for a given resource, then you cannot interact
> with it directly in REST, which means you can't do things like share
> that specific resource with others or use the URI alone as some form
> of audit reference (you can't do that anyway -- you need all of the
> information that typically gets stored in a logfile, including time,
> method, authentication token, etc.).
>
> That does not in any way imply that all resources are direct or,
> conversely, that you cannot have an effect on resources via indirect
> actions under the control of the origin server.  Yes, there are
> trade-offs between the two, and I personally prefer that multi-valued
> resource identifiers always result in a redirection to the more
> specific resource before further actions take place, but both are
> fully equal parts of the REST model.  They allow interaction to be
> vague when specificity is neither desired nor needed, and particularly
> when a component has yet to determine the specific URI.
>
> ....Roy
